repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Rwanda - Poverty Reduction
            Support Series four to seven

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Four to Seven Series
            Poverty Reduction Support Project for Republic of Rwanda
            were as follows: outcome was satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned include: second poverty reduction
            support financing (PRSF) series proved to be effective in
            advancing government-owned reforms. The PRSF series has
            provided important support to the Government to
            operationalize its ambitious medium-term development
            strategy i.e., the economic development and poverty
            reduction strategy (EDPRS) by translating its objectives
            into priority actions. The PRSF series provided substantial
            financing to Rwanda's budget, including during the 2008
            crisis. It was successful in fostering better donor
            coordination, improved harmonization and reinforced support
            for reforms among the country's budget support donors:
            the World Bank, African Development Bank, and bilateral
            donors -all partners in the Budget Support Harmonization
            Group and part of the semi-annual joint budget support
            reviews (JBSR). PRSF series focused on capacity building,
            including sub-national levels of government in planning. The
            success of the PRSF series was also largely helped by its
            ability to base its design on strong sector dialogue. This
            has helped to: (i) ensure the PRSF reflects substantive
            policy agreements reached at the sector level; (ii)
            strengthen the capacity of sector ministries to present
            their needs and priorities during national level policy
            discussions and budget negotiations; and (iii) facilitate
            coordination of the Bank's inputs into the common
            performance assessment framework (CPAF) policy discussions
            in a timely manner. Considering the preparation and
            implementation of the series coincided with the CPAF
            establishment in 2008, this period can be regarded as a
            transition or learning period for all parties involved in
            budget support in Rwanda. Also, growing mutual understanding
            of what each partner would need to get out of the process
            helped it to become smoother over time.
